body:
ping @jdfreder, @ellisonbg, @erccarls, @rsmith31415 for testing

Images are confined to width by default; double-click restores the 'native' size of the image. The `unconfined` metadata allows explicit requests for images to ignore confinement.

Are you sure it is working in Firefox? In Chrome, works fine using `from IPython.display import Image`.

Firefox:

![screenshot from 2015-03-15 16 50 06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6658580/8a314434-cb33-11e4-8432-7a0562548665.png)

Chrome:

![screenshot from 2015-03-15 16 52 51](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6658590/c6cda9be-cb33-11e4-97dc-f63979ac7dc9.png)

I noticed another issue in Firefox. When I click on the div with class `.out_prompt_overlay prompt` (the sidebar near the output), I can't click to change the cell again and the image expands quite a bit to cover the `.out_prompt_overlay prompt` div.

![screenshot from 2015-03-15 16 55 06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6658620/ab34e48c-cb34-11e4-8c27-6dc0fd19c2dd.png)
@rsmith31415 thanks for testing, I'm never sure if anything works in Firefox. That looks wrong in all kinds of ways.
Okay, pushed a small additional max-width, and now it seems to work fine on both FF and Chrome (here, at least). I wasn't able to reproduce the weird overlay you saw, though.
Correct. The second issue has been fixed. Unfortunately, the image (1200x1600, by the way) still overflows in Firefox.
Interesting! I wasn't able to reproduce the second issue, but the first issue was fixed by the recent change for me. I'm at a loss if it still doesn't work on other machines.

You mean the opposite, right? You can't reproduce the first issue (the image overflowing the right side of the notebook) but you fixed the second issue (image overlapping `div.out_prompt_overlay`).

By the way, I'm using Firefox 36.0.1 on Ubuntu 14.10.
@rsmith31415 no. I can reproduce the image overflowing to the right, and the latest commit fixed it. I have not seen the image overlapping the prompt overlay.

I think there was a happy coincidence. After you fixed the image overflowing to the right, the overlapping was fixed. The problem is that the overflowing still remains in Firefox. However, there is no overflowing if I use markdown instead of `from IPython.display import Image`.

The image appears to be constrained to 100% width in Firefox with the latest commit, but it still overflows to the right, because it's offset by the width of the `Out [n]:` prompt:

![screenshot from 2015-03-18 14 06 00](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/327925/6719551/887efe46-cd78-11e4-821f-707248234bb5.png)

Maybe we can use `calc()` to get the correct size?
Double click to switch between width constrained and 1:1 seems to work, and images in markdown cells are correctly constrained to the notebook width.

I noticed that there are different HTML elements (with different classes) being injected depending on the source (e.g. `from IPython.display import HTML` vs `from IPython.display import Image`). Wouldn't it be possible to use a single markup for all of them? I'm saying that because iframes are still overflowing in Chrome and Firefox:

![screenshot from 2015-03-18 15 40 01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6720220/84e68188-cd86-11e4-8783-c9e27732a1ed.png)
In that case, you're explicitly setting width/height in a tag in the HTML. I'm not sure there's much we can/should do about that.

> In that case, you're explicitly setting width/height in a tag in the HTML

max-width takes effect when `width > max-width`. I have it working on every output I produce if I use `*` instead of the `img, svg` in this PR. So we definitely _can_ do something about it. "Should" is less clear.

@rsmith31415 I assume you are referring to the scrolling behavior triggered by clicking on the prompt area, because I was referring to the double-click event we only bind to images.

If we combine this with #7718, then all output will be confined to the area. Arbitrary HTML will overflow in with a scrollbar, and images will shrink to fit. It would also mean that expanding images will not expand them onto the entire page, but rather into a scrolling view that still fits within the width of the notebook. It would make it impossible for images to extend beyond the bounds of the notebook area.

@minrk You're right. I was referring to the prompt because in the last commit, I'm seeing again the image overlapping over the prompt, but this time I find it very hard to reproduce consistently.

There is another issue. If you click twice on the prompt (without double clicking), initially the image remains constrained. But if you double click on the image to let it expand and then click twice again on the prompt, the behavior of clicking on the prompt changes between constraining the image and expanding the image.

Last issue: After reducing the browser, all elements are re-positioned accordingly except the image:

![screenshot from 2015-03-18 18 37 39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6722610/65528a30-cda2-11e4-84c5-20b87f9af577.png)

Images are now the correct size for me.

@rsmith31415 , I'm not sure what you mean about the behaviour of clicking the prompt area after double clicking an image. In my brief tests, it's working as expected.

@takluyver Yes, sorry. I forgot to describe one crucial step to reproduce this issue. Furthermore, now I see that the issue is not really in the prompt but in resizing the browser. Steps:
1. Start your browser maximized and add a large image.
2. Resize your browser:

![screenshot from 2015-03-19 12 14 20](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6737492/8d7b0db8-ce31-11e4-9bd6-804b68e45c91.png)

3 . Double click on the image to expand it.
4 . Maximize your browser (now the image is overflowing):

![screenshot from 2015-03-19 12 16 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6737543/de6b8cfc-ce31-11e4-9310-abc6a04b70ae.png)

5 . Click twice on the prompt. The first click works as expected. The second click returns to the image overflowing.

I seem to be seeing the same things as you, but I'm not sure why you think it's wrong.

There are two separate toggles: image constrained/expanded and output open/scrollboxed. When you switch the output to scrollboxed and back, that doesn't change the image size, so if the image was overflowing before, switching the output area state twice will bring it back to overflowing.

I do see another problem, though. When resizing the window with the image constrained to max width, its size doesn't update as the notebook width updates. I can make it resize in width if I set `max-width: 100%` on the div containing the img (`class="ui-wrapper ui-resizable-autohide"`), but then the aspect ratio isn't preserved.

Yes, I see what you mean. I think I find confusing the feature of expanding the image outside the notebook. There is also the case in which the output is scrollboxed and you double-click to expand within the scrollbox. I think that is very reasonable. Although the image doesn't seem to preserve its dimensions, it seems like a middle ground between the expanded image and the scrollboxed image. By the way, what is the purpose of allowing the image to increase to its original size?

The problem you described is the same I was mentioning before, right? The image is not responsive to resizing the window.

I am fine without images being resizable in the UI. On Thu, Mar 19, 2015 at 6:59 PM, rsmith31415 notifications@github.com wrote: > I finally understood the thing that is causing problems. It is the > .resizable() method http://jqueryui.com/resizable/ from jquery-ui. > Particularly, the following lines: > > ``` > //Create a wrapper element and set the wrapper to the new current internal element > this.element.wrap( > $("
").css({ > position: this.element.css("position"), > width: this.element.outerWidth(), > height: this.element.outerHeight(), > top: this.element.css("top"), > left: this.element.css("left") > }) > ); > > //Overwrite the original this.element > this.element = this.element.parent().data( > "ui-resizable", this.element.data("ui-resizable") > ); > ``` > > This is setting a width and height in pixels to the element ui-wrapper: > > [image: screenshot from 2015-03-19 16 28 38] > https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6742580/8e487e9a-ce56-11e4-84e9-0cad3c9a9d85.png > > Therefore, when we resize the window, the old width and height remain. > This is also adding a class ui-resizable to the image element with the > same width and height than ui-wrapper. By the way, this is the resize > handler that @jdfreder https://github.com/jdfreder was referring to in > the first place. > > I was wondering whether we really need that feature. I didn't even know it > existed. > > — > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub > https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/8062#issuecomment-83794149. ## Brian E. Granger Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo @ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

If removing `.resizable()` is permissible, I think this issue can be solved very easily. I [created](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/compare/master...rsmith31415:css-fix-width-images) a branch with the changes. I tested quickly and works okay:

![output4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/599274/6747819/32a7d1fa-cea4-11e4-8117-92719454ed75.gif)

Thanks for investigating this. Let's see what others think and spend time testing it out.

Sent from my iPhone

> On Mar 20, 2015, at 3:59 AM, rsmith31415 notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> If removing .resizable() is permissible, I think this issue can be solved very easily. I created a branch with the changes. I tested quickly and works okay:
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
I'm fine with removing resize
@rsmith31415 do you want to submit a PR to this PR with your proposed changes to get rid of the resizing?

@ellisonbg I submitted only the removal of the resizer. After that, I think it only takes a few CSS styles to get the main problem fixed. @minkr's PR also includes the feature of expanding the image to its original size but that can be added easily later, if that's what we want.

I don't personally object, but we should be clear that constraining images without being able to easily resize them was what we tried before (#7721), and we got complaints about it from people who wanted to make and look at plots larger than the notebook width, which was part of why we reverted it (#7818). (the other part was that it wasn't consistent across browsers, which I think we've fixed here)
